question: Consider a nonlinear inductor which is defined by $\phi = i + tanh (i)$. Let the current through this inductor be i(t) = sin t. Find the voltage across it (see <image 1>).
options: ['$[1 + sech^2 (sin t)] cos t$', '$[1 + sech^2 (sin t)] sin t$', '$[1 - sech^2 (sin t)] sin t$', '$[1 - sech^2 (cos t)] sin t$']
description:
The image depicts a simple electrical circuit diagram labeled "Fig. 1." The circuit consists of a single component, which is a nonlinear inductor, represented by a coil symbol with an arrow indicating the direction of current flow. The current through the inductor is given as \( i(t) = \sin t \), where \( t \) represents time. 

The voltage across the inductor is denoted as \( v(t) \), and its value is to be determined. The positive terminal of the inductor is marked with a "+" sign, and the negative terminal is marked with a "-" sign. The relationship between the magnetic flux (\( \phi \)) and the current (\( i \)) for this nonlinear inductor is provided as \( \phi = i + \tanh(i) \). 

The task is to find the voltage \( v(t) \) across the inductor when the current \( i(t) \) is \( \sin t \). The options for the voltage are:

A. \( [1 + \text{sech}^2(\sin t)] \cos t \)

B. \( [1 + \text{sech}^2(\sin t)] \sin t \)

C. \( [1 - \text{sech}^2(\sin t)] \sin t \)

D. \( [1 - \text{sech}^2(\cos t)] \sin t \)

The image does not provide any additional information or components in the circuit other than the described nonlinear inductor and the specified current function.
